text: Why is the minimal (non-greedy) match affected by the end of string character '$'?
EDIT: remove original example because it provoked ancillary answers.
The question is why the presence of the "$" in the regular expression effects the greedyness of the expression:

code:
>>> import re
>>> str = "baaaaaaaa"
>>> m = re.search(r"a+$", str)
>>> m.group()
'aaaaaaaa'
>>> m = re.search(r"a+?$", str)
>>> m.group()
'aaaaaaaa'

text: Note the when the "$" is removed, however, then the "?

EDIT:
In other words, "a+?$" is matching ALL of the a's instead of just the last one,  this is not what I expected.
Here is the description of the regex "+?
' after the qualifier makes it perform the match in non-greedy or minimal fashion; as few characters as possible will be matched.
This does not seem to be the case in this example:  the string "a" matches the regex "a+?$", so why isn't the match for the same regex on the string "baaaaaaa" just a single a (the rightmost one)?
